turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- versus City of Louisville, et al.
Mr. Frick, you may proceed with your argument.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: May it please the Court.

I'd like to propose my remarks here with the idea that in a situation of this kind where you have a dispute between an individual and organized society, sympathy is always for the underdog, the individual.
But there's a lot to be said for society, too.
After all, organized society has the duty of preserving order.
As a matter of fact, that was one of the purposes of constitutional government under the Constitution of the United States to ensure domestic tranquility.

And of course, one of the ways of preserving order for all of its citizens is through these offenses and ordinances and statutes relating to loitering, disorderly conduct, vagrancy and minor offenses of that sort.

They are designed to control society to -- to prevent individuals from congregating and as a result of idle minds stirring up crimes, which maybe of a serious nature and thereby injure society and all of the organized group as a whole.
Now, with that theory in mind with which I am approaching this case, I'd like to get to this point.
First of all, it seems to me that this case has been complicated by a certain number of irrelevancies, immaterialities and some speculation.
And I'd like to enumerate what I consider some of those chief irrelevances.
First of all, we have before this Court, a petition to review the proceedings of a single day, that is, the trial of February the 3rd, 1959, in the Louisville Police Court.

The Court will have observed both from the briefs and from the argument that there's been a great deal to say about certain proceedings which happened in the Louisville Police Court on January the 20th.
Now, they may have wondered, as did for some time when I first got into this case, how that happened to get into the record.
In the proceedings of February the 3rd, an agreement was made at page 35 of the record to stipulate the testimony of Dr. Dean.
That was page 34 of the record, I'm sorry, which was given at the trial of January the 20th.

Now, when this stipulation was entered and it was agreed to by the prosecutor, Mr. Dougherty and by the attorney for the petitioner, it was then filed and since that testimony was included with the testimony of all the proceedings of January the 20th, the entire record was filed.
Now, properly therefore, before this Court, there is not the proceedings of January the 20th as such, but only the stipulated testimony of Dr. Dean.
So therefore, after we reach the first 35 pages in the record and the stipulated testimony of Dr. Dean, the remainder is surplusage.
Now --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was there a contention made in the proceeding that we're reviewing that this was simply a course of conduct of harassment against this man?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That was to this extent, an avowal was tendered in which -- prepared by Mr. Lusky on behalf of his client that if he would be allowed to testify, he would testify as follows.
That appears, I think --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That's that avow?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's that avow, yes, sir.
That of course, was not allowed because in the feeling of the trial judge, that was irrelevant.
That -- the issue he had before him was the offense which was charged on February the 3rd.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is the formal charge etcetera, on which we are here?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That appears on the first 35 pages of the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, no, is there a formal charge?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.
It's an informal proceeding.
In other words, the individual was arrested on February the 3rd.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It just came before the magistrate --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: It came before -- it came before the police court in due course --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) a speech may -- made these all.
They're set forth what he claimed was the misconduct of the petitioner.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's -- that's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, where is that in terms?
Where is -- where is the language?
Does one have to be 35 pages to find out what he is charged with?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well [Laughs] the evidence -- there is no formal charge or language that appears --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where did he --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- as such.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- where did he make a statement saying, “Your Honor, we are here because Sam Thompson did the following or misbehaved in the following manner.”
Don't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: As far as the police officer, that does not appear in the record.
The --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You say --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- arresting slip --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You have to take you at your word.
It doesn't appear in the record then I can't tell what he was charged with.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, is there any showing that he violated those charge, that he violated a particular section of the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That -- that is contained in the record.
I am -- it's not included here.
Perhaps, I should take risk.
When an -- when an individual is arrested for a misdemeanor committed in the presence of the officer, he prepares that arrest slip which contains a charge which he has placed against him.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that in the record?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is not in this record, Your Honor

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Would be in the original record though?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Excuse me, sir?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Would be in the original record, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.
I don't believe it's in the original record either, I don't see it in here.
Of course, we didn't prepare this record, but --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is the original record here in the --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- with the clerk?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: It's not with the clerk.
It's down in the office of the clerk of the Police Court in Louisville.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is it -- is it unfair to say that from what you've said without more, one could not find documented what it was that this petitioner really was charged with?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I hadn't thought of that point, but I -- I think you're right, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How can -- how can we -- how can we then determine whether the evidence supports the charge?If you don't know what the charge is, how can you tell whether the evidence supports it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, I know that he was charged with disorderly conduct and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you may know, but [Laughs] --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: [Laughs] But I understand that perfectly, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: If you want --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Excuse me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Go ahead -- go ahead --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: If you went to the records of the police court, would you find a piece of paper there that says --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- section so-and-so --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: -- charged under section --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: -- so-and-so, that's the -- that's the paper that's there in the police court?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.
That is in the possession of the clerk of the police court.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That in --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: It's just a small slip of paper with --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, are the --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: It has the abbreviations for disorderly conduct.
He put down, “D.C.” and for loitering, “Loit” and then they charge under this particular section of the ordinance.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: There is a piece of paper, although it's not here in this Court.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And no matter how informal the police court proceedings may be or how friendly, all the evidence before the police court judge would be -- would have to be confined within the scope of what that charge implied.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.
In other words, that is a ground for frequent objection in police court that evidence is being produced which is not contained within the charge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, if you -- if -- what is the maximum penalty that may be imposed?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: For loitering?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, we have it specified here.
I don't recall offhand.
I believe it's $100.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: $100, I believe.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, if it's decided against that it would -- $20, it could go up to your (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Certainly, if the sentence imposed is $20 or more, it may be appealed as a matter of right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: In other words, that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To the Circuit Court.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right, to the Circuit Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are made then on -- on leave to go to the Court -- to your Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: If it has a jurisdictional amount, it may then be appealed to the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How much is that, $100?
What I want to know is could, could this kind of a case, if a -- if an appropriate fine is imposed, ever reach your Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir, if the penalty was enough.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well then, if it comes before that Court of Appeals, they wouldn't have some documentation of what the charge is in order they can measure the evidence as against the charge.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And we have -- but we're denied that opportunity here on this record, is that it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I don't think deny is exactly the right word.
It's just a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, we haven't got the opportunity.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't even --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I mean --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) by the purposely can (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: We -- we're -- I'm not trying to keep anything from the Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I would like the Court to understand that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm sorry.
If I conveyed such an impression, I didn't mean to.
My language was impermissible.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: But I think both Mr. Lusky and I will be willing to stipulate that he was charged with loitering and disorderly conduct by the appropriate slip of paper in the Louisville Police Court.

turn.speaker: attorney_general
turn.label: Mr. Mr. Attorney General
turn.text: If it please the Court, since counsel has invited a stipulation, I -- I would say that the original record which is in this Court does include the arrest slips, which items 1 and 2 in that record.
I've asked the marshal to get the record and it will be here in a few minutes.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That was an error on my part.
I did not know it was here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How did the -- was there at any time, an attack or is the attack that that statute as such, without further ado, is violative of the Fourteenth Amendment?

Are you going to -- is -- is that in the case, but you have to address yourself to that question or to the question that as applied, meaning by that that there was no evidence to sustain it, a judgment of -- a sentence was secured baseless so far as evidence is concerned?
What is it you're going to speak against, Mr. Frick?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, I've had some difficulty --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- determining it myself, Your Honor.
But as I understand it, one of the complaints made by the petitioner is that he -- his client was convicted without evidence and he had no method of either appeal or corrective judicial review.
Now, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But was there any evidence?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: In my opinion, there was, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What was it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, I think we will recite what the evidence show.
The evidence --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Excuse me, Mr. Frick.
He directed himself now to both of the charges or the separate charges?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: They were separate charges, Your Honor, but they were tried together and the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The loitering?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: The loitering and the disorderly conduct were tried together and the conclusion of the testimony, the judge fixed a sentence of $10 on each offense.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Have you -- you defend both convictions?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: On the same evidence or on different --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: On the same evidence.
There's a --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The same.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- slight difference of evidence and of course, in all these cases for a police court where there are these minor offenses, not a great deal of evidence is adduced.
But briefly, this is what happened.
On this particular occasion, there were two police officers Officer Lacefield and Officer Barnett.
They went into this tavern and barroom known as the Liberty Inn Café.

Under the law of the City of Louisville, by ordinance, a condition is made before the issuance of any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages that it may be entered at any time by a police officer to observe whether or not orderly conduct is being carried on, on the premises.
So, pursuant to that ordinance and as a routine check, these two individuals went into the Liberty Inn Café.

When they arrived in the Liberty Inn Café, one officer testified, the only one who testified, they went up to the manager of the premises and asked him what that fellow was doing, pointing to Sam Thompson.
And they asked him whether or not, he had bought anything to eat or drink while he had been there.
The manager told them that he had bought nothing to eat, nor drink and that he had been there about 30 or 35 minutes.
At this time, the officer testified, “Sam Thompson was standing in the center of the floor dancing by himself, neither eating nor drinking, but merely dancing.”

And Officer Lacefield -- incidentally, Mr. Harlan, the officer who arrested the individual was Mr. Lacefield who did not know at the time of the arrest, anything about the previous trouble that Sam Thompson has been in.
The other officer, Mr. Barnett, told the manager that he knew of some trouble that he had been in at the bus station before.
Now, Officer Lacefield, in arresting this fellow, asked him what he was doing on the premises.
Now, instead of saying that he was there to eat or drink anything, Mr. Thompson said that he was waiting for a bus.
As the officer testified, the Liberty Inn Café faces on Liberty Street, which is a one-way street going west.
If Mr. Thompson wishes to catch a bus, he must go out of that building, go down the street and down to the corner and catch a bus going east.
So, on that basis, apparently, Officer Lacefield felt that there was not a satisfactory account given by Thompson and thereupon, arrested him.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Fink.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Fink.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Frick, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Mr. Fink, may I ask you where you would have had him wait for the bus on this February 9th?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Of course, I am not going to tell anyone where he is to wait, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- five feet -- from five blocks or so from a bus station.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Would you have him wait at the bus station?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I think that he could.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That's where he was arrested for doing that just three days before.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Some time before, Your Honor, but that is not the case which is before us now.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: There is another thing that he -- excuse me.
Excuse me, sir?

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: He would go at gunshot at the bus station.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, that's what he [Laughter] -- that's what his attorney said, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now, here's what he could have done.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose he'd said to the policeman, “It's none of your business why I'm here.”
Would he -- would've -- would he have been within his constitutional rights?
He might have been rude, but would he have been within his constitutional rights if he told him, “It's none of your business?”

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, I would say that under the circumstances, he would not have been within his constitutional rights.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why, because he wasn't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Because, under our ordinance --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Under -- under our ordinance, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would that forbid a man from being in (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.
It does not forbid him there, but he should be there for the business purpose of the proprietor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, what's this --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: And he was not there on a business purpose of the proprietor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is the police --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: He was there loitering.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- what is the policeman's business while a man is in a saloon?
So long as he doesn't misbehave himself overtly.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well [Laughs] --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't understand --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: The -- the business is and under this loitering ordinance, an order to preserve peace, he realize that people loiter, that they will -- but idle minds think of mischief, which will cause damage to society.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Can you loiter inside of a barroom?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is the point that we're --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Loitering means on the street, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, now that gets to the other point.
I would like to answer Mr. Whittaker's question first and then come to you.
Insofar as where he could have waited, Your Honor, he could have waited at the bus stop itself, where he said he would -- intended to catch the bus which was --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) yes, but this was a cold night.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well [Laughs] a number of people have waited on cold nights, Your Honor, for a bus.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Is it a violation of the ordinance of Louisville for an old colored man to go into a bar and to be guilty of loitering and disorderly conduct simply because he taps his foot to music on a barroom floor as he waits for a bus on a cold winter night?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's very dramatic, Your Honor, but I plead what [Laughter] -- that what actually happened, not that he was tapping his foot.
We have to bear this in mind, that where there is a conflict in evidence, Your Honor, and there has been a conviction, that conviction must be supported.
Now, the officer testified --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Must be supported by what?
By evidence.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Evidence, that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: The -- the --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now, the evidence -- there was evidence that he was dancing, evidence of the arresting officer and ultimately, evidence of the manager of the barroom.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What the man to the barroom say?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: On cross-examination, he was asked whether or not, the fellow was doing a shuffle dance and he answered, “Yes that he was.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's precisely (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, he said, “You might call it shuffling,” but I would say he was tapping his feet to music.
Now, isn't that what he said?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir, but I believe --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Is that --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- he also went further.
I believe he admitted that it was a shuffle dance.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I don't know exactly where that is right here in the testimony.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Is that a crime in Louisville?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: On page 27, but Mr. -- question, “But Mr. Thompson was dancing?”
Answer, “He was shuffling around.”
Question, “Doing a kind of shuffle dance?”
Answer, “Yes.”
That's the testimony of the manager of the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What is shuffle (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What is --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Doing a shuffle dance.
Now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What -- what is a shuffle dance?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Your Honor, I -- I presume it is [Laughter] some form of dancing which he uses a system of shuffling.
Now, I was not present [Laughter] -- I was not present, of course and I can't demonstrate to the Court what was involved.
Apparently --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that illegal -- is that illegal in Louisville?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.
Shuffling is not illegal in Louisville.
What is illegal, if it may please the Court, is dancing in the premises licensed to sell liquor.
Now, that does not mean that the person who dances is committing a crime, but merely that the holder of the license is forbidden to permit dancing on his premises.
In other words, a license holder is the one who violates that particular --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And we have got the license holder before us, have we?
We have --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir, we do not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- got a license --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: We do not have a license holder before us, but that demonstrates why this probably was not the type of business for which the operator of the tavern invited the public to attend on his premises.
He certainly would not invite them to attend if, by so doing, he would jeopardize his license.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did the owners --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Oh, pardon me.
Did the owner say he was unwelcomed there?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.
The --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he say he was doing --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: He said that he had no objection to his being there.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: But he did say further --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he say he was doing anything objectionable to him?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: He did not say that he was doing anything objectionable to him in the record.
What he did say was that he would object to dancing, if there were dancing because of course, that would forfeit his license.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If there were dancing.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Or words to that effect, that's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And he saw it, then he said there was nothing objectionable to him.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he say -- did he say that this man did not buy anything or did he say that he didn't serve him anything?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: He said this, “When the -- the police testified that when he came in, that he had neither bought anything to -- neither anything to eat nor drink.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he say --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now, on direct examination --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he say -- did he say positively that he did not buy anything to eat or drink?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: At the trial, he said -- he -- this is what he said positively.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: He said that he did not know whether he had bought anything to eat or drink.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't that different?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: And he could've -- that he could've bought something.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't that different than to say that he did not buy anything, as you have just stated?He said he didn't know of him having buy -- bought anything and he had other people in there who were serving customers, did he not?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then, why do you tell us that he said that he did not buy anything?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: What -- well, Your Honor, if I may tell you what I said --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, it's going to --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I said, when the police officer --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) show me -- show me in the record where -- what he did say.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: On -- now, this is at the time of the officer's testimony --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I don't care when it is.
Just show me in the record where he said the man positively did not buy anything.
That's all I want to know.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: On page 2, Your Honor, testimony of Officer William Lacefield.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Officer Lacefield couldn't testify that he didn't buy anything.
He only came in there at the moment he arrest him.
This man had been in there for half hour.
You were talking about the manager of the -- of the inn.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where did he say the --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Your --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where did he say?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: All right.
Now, let me make this point.
Your Honor, I'm telling you what Officer Lacefield said at the time when he testified as to the arrest.

On this question, he said, “I walked over and asked the bartender if he had bought anything in there and how long he had been there and he told us that he had been there a little over a half hour and that he had not bought anything.”
All right, now, that's what --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's hearsay --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now, that's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's hearsay, isn't it?
You --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You had the --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is hearsay.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The manager himself testified --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- did he not?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now, on the testimony of William Marks (ph) at the trial at -- that's on page 28, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, I have it.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: You do know this question, “You do know this fellow, Thompson, had been there for half an hour and had not eaten anything?”
Answer, “I didn't see him eat anything.”
Question, “If he had had anything to eat or to drink, you would have known about it.”
Answer, “It seems like I would.”
Question, “Because you were there all the time?”
Answer, “Yes.”
Now later on, what Your Honor is referring to, at the bottom of the page, “But you never saw him buy anything.”
Answer, “No.
That don't mean he didn't buy anything.
He was standing out there on the floor.”
That is the part to which Your Honor is referring to.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He didn't say that he never bought anything.
He just said that he didn't see him buy anything.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, that is -- that is true, but --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And he said he could have bought something without his seeing.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, all right.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's all I wanted to know.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: The point that I was making was that at the time of the arrest --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: The point that I was making that at the time of the arrest, according to Lacefield, the arresting officer, he was informed by the manager that he had not bought anything to eat or drink.
That was the point I was trying to make to Your Honor.
And if I didn't do that, I apologize to the Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Frick, may I ask you --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask you -- may I ask you this question.
Assume that one takes your view of the evidence just as you present it, as you stated.

What I would like to have your views on this is whether, under Kentucky law -- Louisville ordinance law, finding a man in the saloon who shuffles, one doesn't know whether he's done it out of exuberance for 2 minutes or for 20 minutes and assume further that he hasn't bought any drink or a sandwich, does that constitute loitering or vagrancy under Louisville ordinance law?A
nd if it does, if that's all the evidence established there, is that consonant with the Fourteenth Amendment?
The two questions I'd like you to answer.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, I think, briefly and this particular case has demonstrated.
It was so held to constitute loitering under the ordinance.
The ordinance provided --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is finding a man in a saloon who happens to shuffle his feet with -- and hasn't bought a drink yet, that constitutes loitering and vagrancy?
And that's what -- and that's the -- if that's the construction of the statute --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- might be the ordinance of the statute, you think that makes -- that doesn't defend the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I think it -- well, of course, Your Honor, this is an ordinance rather than a statute --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, well --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Ordinance of the city --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- for all purposes --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I believe that -- that the facts is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's all there is.
If that's all --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's all -- that's all there is as far as the loitering charge.
As far as the disorderly conduct charge is concerned, that was another piece of evidence (Voice Overlap) which I'd like to tell the Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Frick, may I declare what you just answered to Mr. Justice Frankfurter, as you said that no basis for the conviction for disorderly conduct is relied upon as having happened in the bar, is that true?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And it's only the loitering conviction that depends on what happened in the bar.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Are you're going to go to the disorderly conduct charge as based on what happened on the sidewalk, is that it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: The disorderly conduct evidence --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But before you do that, would you answer whether it's constitutionally allowable for the City of Louisville to make it an offense to be in a barroom and to do nothing else than to shuffle, whatever that may mean or you've said a bit and not have bought a drink or in the barroom, does that -- that's made a crime.Is that allowable under the Constitution of --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, that it is -- with this background, that loitering ordinances and statutes are recognized to be an -- constitutional exercise of power.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, you can't say --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It can't be practically as broad as that.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You cant -- are you suggesting that merely before the legislative body, whether of the state or a city, says something in to be loitering, that's an end of the matter and you he can't inquire into it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.
I don't say that at all, Your Honor, but I'm just giving that background.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now, the next point --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The background you give I can't accept, namely, that all loitering statutes and all vagrancy statutes are constitutional.
I should think there's a great deal to be --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- said to the contrary.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, I think Your Honor is quite right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So this Court has so held in us in the servitude.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Suppose he --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Now, the question is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Suppose he was in a department store and was shuffling alone in a department store and haven't purchased anything for half hour.
Would he be guilty of loitering?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I think, under certain circumstances, he might.
It would depend on the particular facts in this case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: There'd be a lot of women in jail, sir.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, that's true, but now, you make this distinction.
If those women are in there for the business purpose of the store, namely, to shop or to -- or to apprise themselves the prices for the object of future purposes, that would be a different situation.
But where the person would go into a store with not the single desire or purpose ever to indulge in business with that proprietor of those premises --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Ever as long as they live?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Ever as long as they live or at any time at all --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you say that --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I think that under those circumstances, that could constitute loitering.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you say that this evidence shows that -- that this man, no matter how long he might live, had no intention ever of buying anything in this store because of the evidence you have here?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I don't think it does.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, of course --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How does that apply then to the department store?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, what I'm saying is this.
That it's a concept that -- that a business operator invites the public for his business purpose.
Now, the business purpose of this barroom was to sell food and to sell drink.
The business purpose is not to provide a place to wait for a bus, nor is it, quite clearly, a place where one may dance.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't the purpose of a place -- of a place of business what the operator of it considers it to be?
And if he considers a man was properly there, if he wasn't doing anything that was specifically unlawful, isn't he there lawfully?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: But he is there upon the expressed permission of the proprietor or by -- on the implied permission, I think he is there properly.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If he's there under the expressed or implied, you say?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well,

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- didn't -- didn't the owner say that the man was welcome there that he had no objections to him being there and haven't done anything offensive?
What more could you -- what more could you ask to have -- have an implied willingness for him to be there?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I have expressed my opinion, namely, that the implied indication was only for the purpose of the business.
Now, the fact that there are a crowd of people there and there was no objection by the proprietor or the operator of the premises, I think is evidence which should be considered.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- Frick, I don't know about Louisville, but in -- but in New York and Boston, I suppose thousands and thousands of people enter saloons on errands of necessity.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I suppose that's quite true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And don't buy a drink, I mean.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: To -- to get back to the evidence, there's very little evidence of disorderly conduct.

It's contained in the record that, when he is -- that when Sam Thompson was taken outside the barroom, he argued back and forth with the policeman and thereupon, they placed the disorderly conduct charge against him.
That -- that is -- that is the evidence which relates to the disorderly conduct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) that's all you claim that constitute disorderly conduct?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You do not relate the shuffling inside disorderly conduct?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: On one thing --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- what as he got outside, it's in the record inside taken outright while he waited for what you call in the right?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I presume so.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, that's what the record shows to tell me.
There were some arguments between the officers.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, a man protested that he was being persecuted because he's been arrested several times before for minor offenses and there was an argument of it and that's if --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, to the extent of it, I don't know.
The testimony is very sketchy on that part.
It was just that he argued back and forth with the arresting officer and on that basis --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Not disorderly conduct under your ordinance?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, to get back to these offenses again, I don't think it's the greatest evidence in the world, but I think it is sufficient evidence of disorderly conduct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To put a --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: In other words --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- man in jail.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- to create a disturbance on the streets.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: To put a man in jail -- you could put a man in jail for -- for arguing back and forth with the police officer when he's put under arrest, is that correct?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's what happened in this case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you say that's correct?
You should -- is competent evidence and sufficient evidence to send a man to jail?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I think that evidence of argument which results in public disorder is sufficient evidence.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was there anything in the -- in the evidence to say that it resulted in public disorder?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, then why do you add that to it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I don't know how to answer that question.
I think that the first thing to do would be just to read this part of the record which relates to it.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, there -- there isn't -- I don't think anybody is arguing with you that all the evidence shows is that he argued back and forth with the officers about his arrest.
Now --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And that --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I will -- I will say that that's what the evidence shows, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: And not -- not as all that shows --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- in connection with the disorderly conduct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you say that that's sufficient under you laws, to put a man in jail?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's what your court knows.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: To arrest him for disorderly conduct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And to convict him.
That's exactly what this case is about.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Exactly, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Frick, may I ask -- ask -- mind what -- join with me at the top of page 3.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, those three lines, “Went outside, he was very argumentative.
He argued with us back and forth and so then, we placed a disorderly conduct charge on him.”
Is that the whole basis of this conviction?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Of disorderly conduct, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Just those three lines?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Those three lines, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, there's nothing then to indicate his demeanor when he was arguing?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do we know whether it was boisterous or whether it was quiet?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: We know no more than what is contained in those three lines, from one line at the bottom of page 2 and the three lines at the top of page 3.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So that, he might have been discussing his arrest very quietly with the officers.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, if -- if that is compatible with the idea of argument.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, isn't it, or is it?
Do you think it's not?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I -- I do not know whether that is compatible.
It seems to me that the idea of argumentativeness might be loud and -- and normally --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, this is an argument that's going on here.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) but there is -- there's -- there's nothing in the record to indicate it was loud argument or quiet argument or any other kind (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you're making an argument now, aren't you?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I hope so, Your Honor.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is -- isn't this testimony compatible with his having made the same kind of argument with the police officer?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I suppose so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But he said in himself on page 24 with respect to the contrary.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I believe his testimony was to that effect.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is that where you were --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I don't remember.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- were you -- “Were you or not respectful to the officers?”
Answer, “Yes, I was.
I've never been any other way.
I just asked them what they are arrested me for.”
Question, “You didn't argue with them?
You just asked them what they were arresting you for?”
“Yes, I asked what he was locking me up for and he said for loitering and vag” was that, vagrancy?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's vagrancy, yes, sir, Your Honor.
That's a colloquial or abbreviation of the crime of vagrancy.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You say that is a disputed of issue of fact between whatever it meant by the officer's testimony and --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- you were arguing and this man's testimony that he was just an --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: There was no argument.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- impolite inquiry.
You say that's an issue of fact.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That there was no argument.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: What do you say, sir, about the two questions involved, number one, is there any forum in Kentucky where this man might, under these circumstances, seek relief from the judgment of the $10 fine imposed by the police court would have --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I believe that there could have been.
Under Section 110 of our Constitution which is the one that gives to our Court of Appeals jurisdiction over inferior courts.

Now, as mentioned by my opponent, Mr. Lusky, the Kentucky cases are to the effect that the mere monetary amount is insufficient to confer jurisdiction under Section 110 on our Court of Appeals, because that would amount to a substitute for an appeal.

But all of these cases, like Fowler and also in this particular case here, say that where there is a great and irreparable injury that then, an application may be made to Section 110 of the Kentucky Constitution.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But, in this case --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In this case, could an appeal have been taken from this conviction?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To a higher court --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- an appeal could not have been taken.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to a higher court in Kentucky?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: An appeal as such could not have been taken.

I believe that an application could have been made to the Kentucky Court of Appeals under Section 110, the right to control an -- inferior courts setting forth this alleged gigantic conspiracy between the Louisville police judge and the Louisville police force.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And is that --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: And that would have been such a great mere reparable injury that under those circumstances, the Kentucky Court of Appeals would have taken jurisdiction.
Now, let me point out one more thing --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I -- may I shorten, I read this discussion by suggesting that either an appeal could have been taken to a higher court in Kentucky or it couldn't have in whatever the form in which appeals are taken in Kentucky about which I know nothing.

If an appeal is -- could be taken to a higher court, then you should oppose the jurisdiction of this Court because if an appeal could be taken to the highest court, we haven't got jurisdiction of an inferior court.
Now, which is it, could an appeal be taken to a higher court (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I believe that it could have, under the facts in this case, under Section 110 --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you are (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- on the constitution.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When you are to argue against our jurisdiction because you rightly haven't got jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Well, shall I take one minute for that, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I don't know if (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not to please --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Here's the situation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not to please me, but if the law warrants you.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Here's a situation.
In this particular case, there was a writ of habeas corpus applied for to our Circuit Court to stay the execution of the sentence of this police court pending its review by this Court.
It was issued by the Circuit Court.
The City of Louisville objected on the ground that there is no such jurisdiction under our law.
It was appealed to the Court of Appeals.

Now, this is a collateral proceeding on habeas corpus and on this collateral proceeding, the Court of Appeals reversed the circuit judge on a habeas question -- habeas corpus question, saying that it alone had jurisdiction under Section 110 and said further, recognizing this fact that in a $5 or $10 appeal as such, there was no review and therefore, the only remedy was to the Supreme Court of the United States.
They say further, they -- by dicta, they set out this other idea that if there is a great and irreparable injury, this Court will take jurisdiction.
They also recite that this was an extreme case.
Now, I believe that -- without speculating, what a court would have done.

That in this collateral proceeding, if they felt that that was sufficient under Section 110 to take jurisdiction and on their own motion, order a stay of proceedings in the Louisville Police Court so that they might go to this Court.
That that court likewise, if they consider this case as important, would have the authority when the principal case and on the merits, comes before to taking grant relief.
Now, that is my position, but the Court of Appeals was never given an opportunity --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that -- is that argued in your brief, Mr. Frick?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- as such --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is that argued in your brief?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: It's argued some places in my brief.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Where?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I don't remember exactly where.
I'd like to make just one more point.
Now, as far as the Kentucky Court of Appeals is concerned, this is direct from the Louisville Police Court to the Supreme Court of the United States.
The Court of Appeals of Kentucky has not been asked to grant relief to this petitioner on any violations of constitutional rights.
Now, he has constitutional rights both under the Federal Constitution and under our State Constitution.

They had never been asked to do that, so, I don't see how that you can complain about the Kentucky Court of Appeals when they have not had an opportunity to pass on the merits of this question, but only on the collateral point which they considered important enough to grant relief on their own motion.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I wonder if I correctly understood you or you -- if I did, you really said what you meant.
I understood you to say that the Court of Appeals, on this state proceeding, said that the only place where the man could have relief was here.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Did you say that?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That -- that is correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well then, that's to say they couldn't grant any, is it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I don't know what you can say unless the question is presented to a court.
Bear in mind, this is a collateral proceeding.
Under Section 110, the Kentucky Court of Appeals grants relief on its own motion.
They grant a stay of proceedings without being asked for to the petitioner.
Now, if they have that authority and deem it important enough in a collateral manner, they certainly have authority in the principal matter to consider it important enough.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I didn't understand from anything in your brief (Inaudible) again that you claimed that we didn't have jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I believe I raised it.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Where is it?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I didn't make any specific claim as such.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I didn't see it.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: I was talking about the right of -- right of review.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, whether you claim it or not, if there be opportunity of reviewing this police court judgment in a Kentucky court, then we haven't got jurisdiction whether you have brought it home to our understanding or not.
Either there is or isn't, reviewing power in -- from higher court in Kentucky of this police court judgment, if there is, then we have directed jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Is there --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- the only way that I can ask, it may -- we may or may not have jurisdiction in the Kentucky Court of Appeals.
I'd like for the Court to understand that, that it is discretionary under Section 110, whether or not, the Kentucky Court of Appeals will review.
Now, they have said that in a case where there is a simple fine of $5 or $10, they will not grant relief under Section 110.
But, where a great and irreparable injury is done, then they will grant relief under Section 110.
So, Mr. Frankfurter -- Judge Frankfurter, I don't know how to answer your question whether there is or is not an appeal.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: It's speculation.
That's why I've started off by saying that there was speculation in this case.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But you are the one who had asked.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: They were not asked.
That is correct, Your Honor, as such.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understood you to say that they granted relief that was not asked at all.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: They did on the collateral point, that is, a stay of proceedings.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And his relief on what basis?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: On the basis of Section 110, they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: -- say that we have a power under Section 110 of the Kentucky Constitution over control of the inferior courts to grant this right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that the one you say -- is that the one you say they could have granted more relief on -- if that --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- in the regular question, maybe they could?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Maybe they could.
I don't know.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why are -- how are we to assume that they would decide, if they didn't get to this is the only court they had to rely if you are now saying that on the same facts presented to them and asked them to grant direct appeal by the judge?
How can we accuse the -- if that were for your court?
They said, didn't it, that this is the only place you'd get relief.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: They said that in the collateral proceeding.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But now --

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: But now, they were not asked for relief on the other point.
Now, there may or may not --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But they were now being asked for the relief they granted, were they?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Excuse me, sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understood you to say they were not even asked for the relief they did grant.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.
On their own -- on the court's own motion that granted the stay of proceeding in the collateral case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You would ask habeas corpus, a writ.
You would ask for a writ.
There was a -- there was a proceeding before your court indicated by this petitioner.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Initiated by the City of Louisville.
We appealed in the collateral.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you (Voice Overlap) what he did.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He started a -- he started habeas corpus, didn't he?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And he's got to the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: We appealed.
Then --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, you appealed.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Then, the Court of Appeals in the opinion which is attached to this -- an appendix to the petition for certiorari says that we have the power.
We will not require the petitioner to file a new application with us under 110, when we will grant the relief anyhow.
So, we will hereby authorize a stay of proceedings, which was not asked for by the petitioner in the appeal.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I noticed in your -- state constitution says, referring to the power of the Courts of Appeal, said courts shall have power to issue such writs as may be necessary to give it a general control over inferior jurisdiction.
That seems to be very broad.

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: How has that been construed?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: That has been construed for such writs as writs of prohibition to present -- to prevent great and irreparable injury.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Has it been construed to apply to a case where, although there is no direct right of appeal because of the size of the fine, as here, that none (Inaudible) the Court of Appeals under certain situations will issue extraordinary writs to review those cases?

turn.speaker: herman_e_frick
turn.label: Mr. Herman E. Frick
turn.text: No, sir.

There isn't -- there is another case which says that where a constitutional right may be involved, I think it's the Fowler case, where a constitutional right may be involved but the fine is only $5 or $10 and there's no other showing of great or irreparable injury, relief will not be granted.
That's the reverse of the situation.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
